identificationModule.briefTitle: Transcutaneous Vagus Nerve Stimulation for Motor Recovery After Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Safety and Effectiveness of Transcutaneous Vagus Nerve Stimulation Therapy to Improve Motor Recovery After Stroke

responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Assistant Professor, Department of Radiology, Harvard Medical School

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study will evaluate the safety and effectiveness of Respiratory-gated Auricular Vagal Afferent Nerve Stimulation (RAVANS) for improving motor recovery after stroke. Subacute stroke patients will receive RAVANS or sham stimulation concurrent with arm motor training during 10 intervention sessions occurring daily for 30 minutes over 2 weeks. The safety and improvements in arm motor function after the intervention will be compared in patients receiving RAVANS to those receiving sham stimulation.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: This study will evaluate the safety, feasibility and effectiveness of Respiratory-gated Auricular Vagal Afferent Nerve Stimulation (RAVANS) for improving motor recovery after stroke. Subacute stroke patients will be randomized to RAVANS or sham stimulation groups. Patients will receive RAVANS or sham stimulation concurrent with arm motor training during 10 sessions occurring daily for 30 minutes over 2 weeks. Safety will be compared in patients receiving RAVANS to those receiving sham stimulation. Feasibility will be evaluated by recruitment into the study and retention of enrolled patients. Changes in arm motor function will be compared between RAVANS and sham stimulation groups from baseline to immediately after the intervention period and to function at 3-months after stroke.

interventions.name: Active RAVANS concurrent with arm motor training
interventions.description: Patient receives non-painful, sensory-level stimulation to the skin of left outer ear, where nerve endings of the auricular branch of the vagus nerve reside, while participating in arm motor training

interventions.name: Inactive RAVANS concurrent with arm motor training
interventions.description: Patient does not receive stimulation delivered to the skin of left outer ear while participating in arm motor training
